The patient’s symptoms suggest retinal artery occlusion or ischemic optic neuropathy, which can be caused by carotid artery disease. Therefore, the best next step in management is an ultrasound of the carotid arteries. Checking serum inflammatory markers or performing an MRI of the brain may be helpful but are not the most likely causes of the patient’s symptoms. Emergent referral to ophthalmology is not necessary since the ophthalmologic exam was unremarkable.

Carotid artery stenosis is a common underlying cause, and ultrasound of the carotid arteries can help diagnose this. Checking serum inflammatory markers or emergent referral to ophthalmology may not identify the underlying cause, and MRI of the brain is not indicated unless there is suspicion of a central nervous system lesion.

This is often associated with carotid artery disease, which can be detected by ultrasound of the carotid arteries. Checking serum inflammatory markers or ordering an MRI of the brain may be useful in other situations but are not the best next step in this case. Emergent referral to ophthalmology is not necessary if the patient is not currently experiencing vision loss.
